SELECT singer.Name, singer.Song_release_year, singer.Is_male FROM singer_in_concert inner join singer on singer_in_concert.Singer_ID=singer.Singer_ID inner join concert on concert.concert_ID=singer_in_concert.concert_ID inner join stadium on concert.Stadium_ID=stadium.Stadium_ID WHERE singer.Is_male=1 AND concert.Year>=(select average from singer_in_concert where concert.Stadium_ID=stadium.Stadium_ID) group by singer.Name order by singer.Name, singer.Song_release_year;

question: Which models are lighter than 3500 but not built by the 'Ford Motor Company'?
sql: SELECT DISTINCT T1.model FROM MODEL_LIST AS T1 JOIN CAR_NAMES AS T2 ON T1.Model  =  T2.Model JOIN CARS_DATA AS T3 ON T2.MakeId  =  T3.Id JOIN CAR_MAKERS AS T4 ON T1.Maker  =  T4.Id WHERE T3.weight  <  3500 AND T4.FullName != 'Ford Motor Company';

question: Which are the car makers which produce at least 2 models and more than 3 car makers ? List the id and the maker .

A relational database is a collection of information that is organized so that it can be easily accessed, managed, and updated. Relational databases are organized into tables, in which rows are the individual pieces of information and columns are the fields.
To see a real world example of a relational database, check out the example below, which contains a DB created using the DBeaver tool.
The fields in a relational database table are referred to as columns and the rows are referred to as records.
A relational database is an organization of data that is designed to allow the user to perform certain operations on the data. For example, a relational database may be designed to allow a user to find a specific record based on a particular field, such as the customer's name.
Relational databases are designed around the concepts of the Relational Database Model, which was proposed in 1970 by E. F. Codd. Relational databases use a conceptual database model that differs from a physical database model

SELECT a.UID, COUNT(DISTINCT (a.uid)) AS uid_cnt, a.airline, b.airport_name, c.airport_code, d.country FROM airlines a INNER JOIN flights b ON a.uid = b.airline INNER JOIN airports c ON c.airport_code = b.source_airport INNER JOIN airports d ON d.airport_code = b.dest_airport GROUP BY a.airline, c.airport_code, d.country;.

A transaction deadlock occurs when two or more users try to lock the same resource at the same time.

A transaction is a unit of work performed by a DBMS to process a set of data in a database, such as a set of data entered by a user, a set of data modified by the user, or a set of data updated by the DBMS.
What is the definition of "DBMS"?
A DBMS (Database Management System) is an application that acts as an interface between the user and the underlying database.

CREATE VIEW Document_Templates_View
AS SELECT
Document_ID,
Template_ID,
Document_Name,
Document_Description,
Other_Details
FROM Documents
2. Create a view as:
CREATE VIEW Document_Template_Details_View
SELECT Paragraph_Text
FROM Paragraphs
WHERE Template_ID = 9470720
AND Document_ID = 9546701
We will then join these two views as:
SELECT Paragraph_Text
FROM Document_Template_Details_View
The column names in the first table must be prefixed with 'V_' followed by the name of the view. It's just a naming convention, so that we know which view we are joining on.

SELECT Document_ID, MAX(Version_Number) AS Latest_Version_Number FROM Documents WHERE MAX(Version_Number) <= 2 GROUP BY Document_ID
I was able to find all documents with more than two paragraphs and then found the last version number (which is the version with the most paragraphs). Here is my query:
SELECT Document_ID, MAX(Version_Number) AS Latest_Version_Number FROM Documents WHERE MAX(Version_Number) <= 2 GROUP BY Document_ID
I took the results and matched it to the template_id from the templates table and it gave me the documents with the paragraphs.
You'll note that the two tables are joined with a subquery in the FROM clause. This is called a self-join. A self-join can be used to find all the rows in one table that are also in the other.
Note: The method in which you select the rows from each table can be quite different. I chose to select all the rows from the Documents table first. This allows me to sort the rows by version number to get the latest version. The version number is needed to identify the template_id.

Given a positive integer N, the N greatest positive integers are the integers that appear at most once in the sequence. For example, in the sequence 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9, the 3 greatest positive integers are 3, 5, 8.

Bankers with more than $1 trillion in assets in the United States have been pressuring regulators for years to ease capital requirements on the most valuable assets they hold—mortgage bonds and other loans. Now the regulators seem to have listened. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency said on Thursday that it would allow the nation’s biggest banks to treat a majority of the loans on their books as if they were riskier than they really are. Most of the banks are expected to take advantage of the new rule, which will reduce the amount of capital they must set aside to guard against losses. Answer: This will do what you want.

\begin{code}
select
    c.continent,
    sum(c.population) as population,
    avg(cl.life_expectancy) as life_expectancy
from
    country c
    left join country_language cl on cl.country_code = c.country_code
    join
        city c1 on c.code = c1.code
group by
    c.continent, cl.language
\end{code}

SELECT Performance_ID, (SELECT AVG(Attendance) FROM Show WHERE Performance_ID=P.Performance_ID) AS Attendance FROM Performance AS P WHERE P.If_first_show=1 GROUP BY Performance_ID HAVING Attendance>0

What is a Unique Key? What are Foreign Keys?
A Unique Key is a column in a table that contains all unique values from that column. A Foreign Key is a column in a table that refers to the primary key of another table.
What is the difference between a primary key and a unique key?
A primary key is a field in a table that uniquely identifies a single record in a table. A unique key is a field in a table that contains all unique values from that column.
What are the types of indexes? Give an example of each.
The most common types of indexes are: B-tree index. A B-tree index is a tree structure in which the index is stored. A B-tree index is fast and efficient. Hash index. A hash index is an index in which each record is a separate file. A hash index is fast and efficient. B-tree index with a hash index. A b-tree index with a hash index is fast and efficient.
